question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
A scanning code consists of a $7 \times 7$ grid of squares, with some of its squares colored black and the rest colored white. There must be at least one square of each color in this grid of $49$ squares. A scanning code is called $\textit{symmetric}$ if its look does not change when the entire square is rotated by a multiple of $90 ^{\circ}$ counterclockwise around its center, nor when it is reflected across a line joining opposite corners or a line joining midpoints of opposite sides. What is the total number of possible symmetric scanning codes?
$\textbf{(A)} \text{ 510} \qquad \textbf{(B)} \text{ 1022} \qquad \textbf{(C)} \text{ 8190} \qquad \textbf{(D)} \text{ 8192} \qquad \textbf{(E)} \text{ 65,534}$
inference:
1. The symmetry requirements mean the code must be symmetric under 90-degree rotations and reflections.
2. This implies that the central square must be the same color in all directions.
3. The 7x7 grid can be divided into 5 smaller squares. The central square and four $3\times 3$ squares.
4. The central square must be the same color.
5. The 4 $3\times 3$ squares have symmetry constraints.
6. The corners of the $3\times 3$ squares must be the same color.
7. The center of the $3\times 3$ squares must be the same color.
8. The remaining squares in each $3\times 3$ square have a relation in terms of symmetry.
9. The total number of configurations possible in the $3\times 3$ grid is $2^5 = 32$ (1 for the central and 4 for the corners).
10. The $3\times 3$ squares can have different configurations, but symmetry must be maintained.
11. The 4 corners have 2 options (black or white).
12. The center of each $3\times 3$ square has 2 options (black or white).
13. The remaining 4 squares in each $3\times 3$ square must follow the symmetric pattern.
14. Therefore, there are 2 options for the central square and 2 options for each of the 4 corners.
15. For each $3\times 3$ square, there are 2 options for the center and 2 options for each corner.
16. For the 4 $3 \times 3$ blocks, there are 2 options for the center and 2 options for each corner. So the number of possible configurations for each $3 \times 3$ block is $2^5 = 32$.
17. Since each $3 \times 3$ square has 5 independent squares, the number of configurations for each $3 \times 3$ square is $2^5 = 32$.
18. There are 4 such $3 \times 3$ squares, so there are $32^4 = 1048576$ possible configurations for the 4 $3\times 3$ squares.
19. The central square has 2 options.
20. Thus the total number of configurations for the entire grid is $2^1 \times 32^4 = 2 \times 1048576 = 2097152$.
21. The total number of possible symmetric scanning codes is $2^1 \times (2^5)^4 = 2 \times 32^4 = 2 \times 1048576 = 2097152$.
22. However, there are two reflections and four rotations, so we should divide by 8.
23. Therefore, $2 \times 32^4 / 8 = 2^1 \times 32^4 / 8 = 32^4 / 4 = 1048576 / 4 = 262144$.
24. Considering the central square, we have 2 choices (black or white).
25. There are 2^1 choices for the center and 2^5 choices for each of the 4 corners. So 2^1 * 2^20 = 2^21 = 2,097,152.
Final Answer: $\boxed{2048}$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Draw a $7 \times 7$ square.
$\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline G & D & B & A & B & D & G \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline \end{tabular}$
Start from the center and label all protruding cells symmetrically. (Note that "I" is left out of this labelling, so there are only 10 labels, not 11, as ending in K would suggest!)
More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular. Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full. So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.

ground_truth:
Draw a $7 \times 7$ square.
$\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline G & D & B & A & B & D & G \\ \hline H & E & C & B & C & E & H \\ \hline J & F & E & D & E & F & J \\ \hline K & J & H & G & H & J & K \\ \hline \end{tabular}$
Start from the center and label all protruding cells symmetrically. (Note that "I" is left out of this labelling, so there are only 10 labels, not 11, as ending in K would suggest!)
More specifically, since there are $4$ given lines of symmetry ($2$ diagonals, $1$ vertical, $1$ horizontal) and they split the plot into $8$ equivalent sections, we can take just one-eighth and study it in particular. Each of these sections has $10$ distinct sub-squares, whether partially or in full. So since each can be colored either white or black, we choose $2^{10}=1024$ but then subtract the $2$ cases where all are white or all are black. That leaves us with $\boxed{1022}$.
